title: Netflix Ditches 'One Day at a Time' Reboot
summary: The decision, which drew criticism from fans, comes as the streaming service has emerged as a dominant force in the entertainment industry. Netflix Inc. said Thursday it was canceling the comedy "One Day at a Time" because of low viewership, a decision that drew criticism from some fans and critics and underscored how the streaming-video giant is under a microscope as it becomes a bigger player in original programming.

title: Facebook, Google, Apple Hit by Outages
summary: Separate disruptions at tech giants appear to be coincidence. Computer systems at three of the world's largest technology companies went offline temporarily this week, thanks to an unusual and apparently coincidental series of glitches at Facebook Inc., Google and Apple Inc.

title: At Hudson Yards, Coffee Sellers Will Grind It Out
summary: Resume Subscription. In hyper-caffeinated New York City, coffee drinkers never have to venture far for a cup. But at Hudson Yards-the mega development on Manhattan's far West Side that opens Friday-they may be overwhelmed by the possibilities.

title: Senate Passes Resolution to Block Trump's Border Emergency
summary: Bill now heads to White House, where president is expected to veto it. WASHINGTON-A dozen Senate Republicans joined Democrats on Thursday to reject President Trump's emergency declaration at the southern border, rebuking the president on his signature policy issue after he pushed to use funds that weren't appropriated by Congress.

title: Who Is Beto O'Rourke?
summary: He's the fresh, elusive outsider like Carter, Clinton and Obama..

title: Two Top Facebook Executives Leaving Company
summary: Exits come days after CEO Mark Zuckerberg said he wanted to shift Facebook's focus more to private messaging and communications. A senior Facebook Inc. executive viewed as a potential successor to Mark Zuckerberg abruptly stepped down Thursday, signaling that he disagrees with the CEO's new focus on private messaging at the social-networking giant.

title: Trump Loses the Senate
summary: A dozen Republicans send a message about the power to spend.. The Senate voted Thursday to override President Trump's declaration of a national emergency on the southern border, and Mr. Trump said even before the vote was over that he'll veto the resolution. While the 59-41 vote won't have immediate policy impact, the magnitude of the 12 GOP defections is a warning about the needless harm Mr. Trump is doing to himself and his party.

title: The Club for Growth of Identity Politics
summary: An ad criticizes Beto O'Rourke for white male privilege.. Fringe campus politics has gone mainstream, and identity politics is a core Democratic tenet. So it's unfortunate to see this rancorous ideology also adopted by the right as a political weapon.

title: Berlin's Bad Bank Idea
summary: Germany needs fewer little banks instead of one mammoth one.. As bad banking ideas go, Berlin's proposed merger between Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank is in a special league. German politicians seem to think they're creating a national financial champion. The result instead would be a bank that's too big to succeed, too big to fail, and too big to save in a crisis.

title: Brazilian Police Poised to Arrest Third Suspect Identified in School Shooting
summary: Attack on campus near São Paulo left 10 dead and another 11 injured. SÃO PAULO-Brazilian police have requested an arrest warrant Thursday for a third suspect allegedly involved in the country's brutal school shooting, saying they believe the group's main goal was to kill more people than the 1999 Columbine massacre in the U.S.

title: Kids, Don't Become Success Robots
summary: Tennessee Tech is an amazing school, and nobody breaks the law to get admitted.. A few thoughts on the college admissions scandal in which wealthy and accomplished parents allegedly lied, cheated and bribed to get their kids admitted to elite universities.

title: Trump and Jared's Clearance
summary: Conservatives gain a healthy skepticism about intel agencies, but liberals lose it.. Much of the national-security commentariat is appalled by President Trump's decision to intercede in the clearance process for Jared Kushner, who is Mr. Trump's son-in-law. Without the president's intervention, Mr. Kushner and probably his wife, Ivanka Trump, wouldn't have received top-secret clearances, which are required for senior positions in the White House. Recent reports suggest that Mr. Trump lied about his involvement in the matter, indicating he might have known his intercession was unseemly.

title: Oracle's Revenue Declines as It Struggles to Catch Up in the Cloud
summary: Company offers flat to weaker revenue outlook for current quarter as some rivals post double-digit gains. Oracle Corp. said its revenue fell 1% in its latest quarter, a second-consecutive period of decline as the software giant continues to struggle adapting its business for the cloud era.

title: Buddhism as a National-Security Threat
summary: After Pearl Harbor, Japanese-Americans found their faith under attack.. Today most Americans think of Buddhism as either benign or cool. But not long ago the federal government deemed the religion an un-American threat to national security.

title: Shocked by Biased Journalism? Please.
summary: Democrats make a mistake in trying to freeze out Fox News.. The Democratic National Committee will regret its decision to bar Fox News from hosting any of its 2020 presidential primary debates. Just as the game begins, the committee has planted the idea that the Democrats mean to run a rigged election-not a happy thought to encourage in view of the way the party's leaders fiddled with the process in 2016 to favor Hillary Clinton over Bernie Sanders.

title: 'Saint Patrick Retold' Review: The Patron Saint of Ireland
summary: Credited with converting the Emerald Isle to Christianity, Patrick was actually a Roman subject from Britain.. St. Patrick's Day is upon us, and with it the celebrations and occasional controversies associated with the eponymous patron saint of Ireland-the distinctly non-Irish missionary credited with converting the Emerald Isle to Christianity in the fifth century. The Irish around the world will mark the anniversary of Patrick's death this weekend with parades, concerts, poetry readings and lectures, only some of which will bear any relation to the saint's life and work. Thanks to the size and cultural power of the Irish diaspora, these annual rituals have transformed Patrick into a saintly superstar of global significance.

title: Trump's Big Trade Opening
summary: The impending deal with China is a chance for America to lead a new era of liberalization.. President Trump has taken an unconventional approach to international trade. He has criticized existing agreements with allies, imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum from friends and foes alike, and escalated conflict with the world's second-largest economy, China. Whether by design or serendipity, tough talk and blunt action have provided Mr. Trump with a series of opportunities to advance the cause of free trade more consequentially than his recent predecessors.

title: Brexiteers Face Reality-They Need the Political Class After All
summary: British voters want an activist state. They can't afford to reject the people who are able to run it.. Somewhere around three weeks ago, it became impossible for mere mortals to follow Brexit anymore.

title: Democrats, Stop Pretending to Be Socialists
summary: The vibrancy and magic of capitalism are entirely compatible with a strong social safety net.. If this be socialism-oh, never mind.

title: Southern Poverty Law Center Fires Co-Founder
summary: The Alabama nonprofit cites an unspecified personnel issue for the move. The Southern Poverty Law Center announced Thursday it had fired its co-founder Morris Dees, citing an unspecified personnel issue.

title: S&P 500 Slips, but Blue Chip Stocks Eke Out Gain
summary: Mounting signs of a global economic slowdown have kept this year's rally in check lately. The S&P 500 snapped a three-day winning streak, as investors continued to weigh global trade tensions and concerns about slowing economic growth.

title: Maker of AR-15 Can Be Sued Over Sandy Hook Massacre, Court Rules
summary: Connecticut Supreme Court allowed victims' suit to move forward over its marketing of the gun. The gun industry suffered a potentially significant legal setback Thursday when the Connecticut Supreme Court said a leading maker of AR-15 rifles could be held legally responsible for marketing practices that allegedly made the semiautomatic gun the weapon of choice for mass shooters.

title: British American Tobacco's Canadian Unit Files for Bankruptcy in U.S.
summary: Subsidiary, sued by Quebec smokers for hiding health risks, was ordered to pay 9.2 billion Canadian dollars. British American Tobacco PLC put one of Canada's top cigarette distributors into bankruptcy protection in the U.S. after that subsidiary, sued by Quebec smokers in 1998 for hiding health risks, was ordered to pay 9.2 billion Canadian dollars (US$6.9 billion).

title: From High School Basketball Coach to Ringleader of the Nation's Largest College-Admissions Scam
summary: Aggressive and competitive, William Rick Singer's intensity was notable even as a basketball coach in the 1980s. The slight 58-year-old man at the center of the far-reaching college-admissions scandal that has caught up Hollywood stars and Wall Street executives started out as a high-school basketball coach in California.

title: House Votes for Public Release of Mueller Report
summary: The resolution passes the chamber without a dissenting vote. WASHINGTON-The House passed a resolution-with overwhelming bipartisan support-calling for a public release of special counsel Robert Mueller's anticipated report on his investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.

title: Push to Expand Prevailing Wage Sparks Budget Fight in Albany
summary: Business and development organizations lobby against a measure to expand the definition of public works. Building trade unions and business groups are battling over a New York budget provision that would expand the definition of public works that require higher wage rates.

title: Israel Says Two Rockets Fired From Gaza Toward Tel Aviv, Raising Tensions
summary: No injuries or damage from the attack were reported. TEL AVIV-Israel's military said Thursday two rockets were launched from the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip toward Tel Aviv for the first time since the 2014 war, setting off sirens in the city and raising tensions.

title: Facebook's Family Matters
summary: Chris Cox is the latest-and greatest-executive to exit the social network. Anybody who doubted whether Mark Zuckerberg was serious about Facebook 's new direction should think again.

title: New York City Plans Shoreline Expansion to Prevent Flooding
summary: Mayor says coastal extension could cost $10 billion. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio proposed Thursday to extend the East River shoreline of lower Manhattan by as much as 500 feet, or two city blocks, to protect the financial district and South Street Seaport from flooding tied to climate change.

title: The Aerospace Newcomer Whose Data Helped Make the Difference on Grounding the 737 MAX
summary: Aireon's satellite system tells airlines and air-traffic-control partners about speed, heading, altitude. When the Federal Aviation Administration reversed course and grounded Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX jetliner, it moved partly after seeing data from a little-known aerospace newcomer that is changing the way the aviation industry tracks planes.

title: HR Departments Turn to AI-Enabled Recruiting in Race for Talent
summary: As the battle for talent becomes more competitive, companies are turning toward artificial intelligence to help with recruiting and other human resources tasks. Artificial intelligence is helping companies across industries answer human resources-related questions, automate some HR tasks and suggest jobs to prospective candidates. In the future, the technology will become even more common in hiring and recruiting, executives say.

title: Mark Penn's Stagwell Group Takes Stake in MDC Partners
summary: Mr. Penn will become MDC's CEO and join its board of directors. Stagwell Group, an ad company founded by Mark Penn, agreed to acquire a minority stake in ad-holding company MDC Partners Inc. for $100 million, the companies said Thursday.

title: Tesla CFO Moves to Rebuild Finance Team With New Accounting Chief
summary: New Tesla finance chief moves to refill his finance team, promotes insider to chief accounting officer. Tesla Inc. finance chief Zach Kirkhorn's first-day move to replenish his finance team aims to reassure insiders and investors and rebuild the auto maker's executive ranks after a wave of departures.

title: 'The Inventor: Out for Blood in Silicon Valley' Review: A Bitter Pill
summary: Alex Gibney's documentary looks at Elizabeth Holmes, whose notorious Theranos promised to revolutionize health care.. The phrase "fake it till you make it" is heard more than once during "The Inventor: Out for Blood in Silicon Valley," director Alex Gibney's enthralling documentary about the mesmerizing Elizabeth Holmes-who faked it till she got indicted. Her company, the now-notorious Theranos, was supposed to revolutionize medical diagnostics and bring walk-in blood testing to places like Walgreens. Instead, it went from a valuation of $9 billion to being less than worthless. Ms. Holmes's story, conversely, is priceless, especially in Mr. Gibney's psycho-cinematic retelling.

title: Dollar Gains Against Emerging-Market Currencies
summary: Signs of a slowing Chinese economy are worrying for developing countries. The dollar rose against emerging-market currencies Thursday, as investors reacted to weaker-than-expected Chinese data.

title: GE Warns of Another Year of Falling Profits
summary: Conglomerate calls 2019 a "reset year". General Electric Co. warned investors of another year of lower profits and weak cash flow from its core industrial operations, but the forecast was in keeping with the conglomerate's recent cautionary outlook.

title: 'The Fix' Review: Vengeance on Trial
summary: A prosecutor returns to her old job after a man she failed to convict years before is once again suspected of murder.. There's not a jury in the country that would find "The Fix" innocent of being a shameless revenge fantasy, even on the basis of circumstantial evidence (namely, the first two of 10 episodes). If the plotline fits, you can't acquit.

title: Former Democratic Indiana Sen. Birch Bayh Dies at 91
summary: He was noted for push for landmark federal 'Title IX' law prohibiting gender discrimination in education. INDIANAPOLIS-Former Democratic Indiana Sen. Birch Bayh, who won three terms to the Senate and was a key sponsor of the landmark 1972 federal law banning discrimination against women in college admissions and athletics, died Thursday at age 91, his family said.

title: Rubio Defends His Opposition to Stock Buybacks
summary: I believe our policies should unambiguously support capital investment.. For an editorial board that regularly invokes President Ronald Reagan, the Gipper's axiom that "the person who agrees with you 80% of the time is a friend and an ally-not a 20% traitor" no longer seems to hold true. Case in point is your editorial "The Stock Buyback Panic" (March 11) criticizing my efforts to enact pro-growth, pro-worker reforms.

title: On the Overmedication of School Children
summary: Governments give more money to schools that show more problems. The more children diagnosed with a disability at a school, the more money a state or federal program would allocate to that school.. Regarding Erica Komisar's "We're Overmedicating Our Children" (op-ed, March 7): Governments give more money to schools that show more problems. The more children diagnosed with a disability at a school, the more money a state or federal program would allocate to that school.

title: Democracy and Capitalism Both Best Enable Prosperity
summary: I cannot help but wonder if the turn toward socialism in both the U.S. and Western Europe hasn't also played a significant role in this downturn of economic power.. Regarding "When Democracy Is No Longer the Only Path to Prosperity" (Review, March 2): I agree with the premise that the rise of authoritarian capitalism has had an impact on liberal democracy and the decline in economic power. However, I cannot help but wonder if the turn toward socialism in both the U.S. and Western Europe hasn't also played a significant role in this downturn of economic power.

title: Many Justices Were Never Judges Before Appointment
summary: It turns out that some of the most highly regarded Supreme Court justices share the lack of prior judicial experience with Neomi. Rao: John Marshall, William Rehnquist, Lewis Powell Jr., Abe Fortas, Earl Warren, William Douglas, Felix Frankfurter, Louis Brandeis and Elena Kagan.. John Terranova's (Letters, March 9) opposition to the nomination of Neomi Rao to the federal bench rests his case on her lack of judicial experience. It is true that Ms. Rao has no prior judicial experience, but has that been a major qualification for judicial appointment?

title: 'The Mustang' Review: Kindred Spirits in Collision
summary: A prison inmate bonds with a wild horse as he trains it in Laure de Clermont-Tonnerre's debut feature.. Getting a good idea for a movie doesn't guarantee that the movie will be good. Clichés beckon. Pitfalls multiply. Parallels invite clarification. Symbols beg for emphasis. "The Mustang" starts with a fine idea-an incorrigible prison inmate learns to tame his own wild rages by taming, and training, a wild mustang. Far from going wrong, though, this debut feature by Laure de Clermont-Tonnerre opens strong, grows even stronger and, avoiding almost every trap, fulfills its abundant promise. However many films you may have seen about the bond between humans and horses, here's one that will move you anew.

title: 'Ash Is Purest White' Review: Shifting Worlds
summary: Jia Zhang-ke paints a portrait of a quickly changing China in this story about a strong woman and her small-time mobster boyfriend.. At the pivot point of Jia Zhang-ke's "Ash Is Purest White," the girlfriend of a small-time mobster grabs a gun, fires it and saves him from being beaten to death by a gang of hoodlums. Everything else in this violent love story flows from that one fateful act-whirlwind feelings and events played out amid the hurtling changes of modern China. No one makes movies like Mr. Jia does. He's a dramatist with the eye of a documentarian and the instincts of a historian, even a geographer. But he's also a romantic poet, and his heroine, a strong woman with a pure heart, is driven by love as far as it can take her.

title: The Science Behind Why We Use 'F' Words
summary: Ancient diet changes may have altered how humans speak and spawned an increase in the use of words that include 'F' sounds. A change in ancient diet may have altered the way humans speak, and potentially spawned an increased use of words that include "f" and "v" sounds, says a new study that may offer insights into the development of language.

title: Dollar General Warns of Slower Sales Growth
summary: Discount retailer plans to introduce a new line of fresh-food items and is working to create a digital and e-commerce strategy that appeals to its core shoppers. Dollar General Corp. on Thursday said same-store sales grew in the most recent quarter, but profit was less than expected as the retailer invests in lower prices and increases the portion of sales that come from less profitable products like food.

title: Investors Embrace Riskier Sectors as Stocks Extend Rebound
summary: Equities tied to tech and economic cycles outperforming rest of market, buoying confidence in rally. Stock sectors that tend to gain when investors are embracing risk or expecting faster growth have performed better than others as major indexes approach last year's peaks, boosting some analysts' confidence the rally will continue.

title: Reputed Gambino Crime Boss May Have Been Lured to His Death
summary: Investigators are looking into whether man's killer hit his sport-utility vehicle to get him outside his Staten Island house. Investigators are looking into whether the suspect who killed Francesco Cali hit the sport-utility vehicle of the reputed Gambino crime family boss to lure him outside his Staten Island home.

title: The Yale Dad Who Set Off the College-Admissions Scandal
summary: Morrie Tobin was implicated in a securities fraud case when he mentioned a bribe sought by a Yale coach. The tipster who led federal authorities to the biggest college-admissions scam they have ever prosecuted was Morrie Tobin, a Los Angeles financial executive who was being investigated in a securities fraud case, according to a person familiar with the investigation.

title: Beto O'Rourke Announces 2020 Presidential Run
summary: Texan who narrowly lost Senate race in '18 brings national profile, fundraising clout to crowded contest. BURLINGTON, Iowa-Former Texas Rep. Beto O'Rourke joined the 2020 presidential race Thursday, aiming to parlay his turn as one of the Democratic stars of the 2018 midterm elections into a run at his party's nomination.

title: Defamation Case Against Trump Cleared to Move Forward, Court Rules
summary: Decision says 'the President is still a person, and he is not above the law,' overruling his request to stop a two-year-old lawsuit. President Trump must face a defamation lawsuit brought by a former reality-show contestant, a New York appellate court ruled Thursday, striking down his argument that a sitting president should be shielded from such claims.

title: Treasurys Edge Lower Despite Tepid Housing Data
summary: Government bonds remain largely range-bound. U.S. government-bond prices edged lower Thursday, falling for a second straight session as traders continued to pull back after a recent spate of buying.

title: Brexit Could Bring Changes to U.K. Sanctions Policy
summary: Britain gains flexibility to potentially chart its own course, but is expected to remain closely aligned with European partners. Britain's exit from the European Union could bring significant changes to the country's sanctions policy.

title: Boeing Rebuked Over Tanker
summary: Air Force won't regain full confidence in plane maker's quality control for at least a year, says top official. The U.S. Air Force has lost confidence in Boeing Co. 's ability to maintain quality control over a new aerial refueling tanker it is building, with a senior Pentagon official saying Thursday that it could take at least a year to rebuild trust in the program.

title: The New Rules for Airplane Dressing: Chic, Yet Comfortable
summary: Like it or not, the modern travel uniform has become deeply casual. How to hack it so you're presentable but still feel good. WHILE IN Manhattan this February for her baby shower, the newish Duchess of Sussex left her hotel wearing a markedly plebeian outfit: black leggings, Adidas running shoes and a black baseball cap. Despite appearances, Meghan Markle was not headed to the gym; she was en route to the airport. (By contrast, Princess Diana almost always wore heels to the airport in the 1980s, typically with skirt suits and stockings.) Considering that royals are among the last holdouts of etiquette and glamour, the Duchess's outfit seemed to confirm an unstylish truth: We now dress for air travel as indifferently as we would to step on a treadmill in our basement gyms.

title: Ethiopian Airlines Crash Highlights FAA's Diminished Global Clout
summary: U.S. regulators, unable to initially pinpoint a specific 'unsafe condition,' resisted international pressure to ground flights. Two fatal crashes of Boeing Co. 737 MAX jets less than five months apart diminished the standing of the Federal Aviation Administration even in the eyes of some supporters, since the agency certified the model as safe.

title: Oil Prices Hit 2019 High as U.S. Sanctions Bite
summary: Crude prices have climbed to four-month highs for the past two sessions, helped largely by U.S. sanctions on both Iran and Venezuela. • U.S. oil prices rose to their highest level of the year Thursday as U.S. sanctions on both Venezuela and Iran begin to put a tighter squeeze on global oil supplies.

title: Earning a Spot in Modernism's Pantheon
summary: As an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art makes clear, Lincoln Kirstein may have been a scattershot artist who created little worthy of posterity, but he is worth rememberingfor his dedication to supporting the genius of George Balanchine..

title: Cut That Out: 11 Rules of Barbershop Etiquette
summary: We asked barbers who've seen it all. Rule No. 7: 'Don't climb in the chair filthy with a beard full of mustard and chili'. "No Religion. No Politics. No Phones during service," reads the sign that bluntly greets customers at Vinny's Barber Shop in Los Angeles. The first two rules were passed down to owner Omar Romero by a mentor aiming to avoid unnecessary squabbles in his shop. The third, he said, is a necessity in these distracted times. "If a customer picks up the phone to talk, you can't cut around their ears, you have to turn off the clippers," Mr. Romero explained, adding that the rules are rather lightly policed.

title: 'Be More Chill' Review: Young Geeks in Love
summary: The musical about socially struggling high schoolers whom a drug makes popular moves to Broadway.. New York

title: Syrian, Russian Airstrikes Target Rebels in Last Stronghold
summary: Attacks on Idlib in northwest Syria come as the United Nations seeks aid for Syrians struggling to cope with years of conflict. BEIRUT-Syrian government and Russian airstrikes on the last rebel stronghold in Syria have intensified in recent days, raising fears of a military offensive that the United Nations has long warned would cause a humanitarian disaster.

title: A Proper Roast Dinner, Any Night of the Week
summary: There's nothing like a Sunday roast-except this pared-down version from the chefs at London's Marksman Public House. The recipe pairs quick-cooking veal steaks and braised spring onions with a hearty potato mash. IN ENGLAND everyone has an opinion regarding the Sunday roast. Chefs Jon Rotheram and Tom Harris count on receiving feedback weekly when they serve the ritual meal at Marksman Public House, in East London. The roast, it seems, belongs to everybody. "It reminds people of their nans," Mr. Harris said. "Ours isn't at all restaurant-y," Mr. Rotheram added. "It feels comfy, like a bit of a hug."

title: Best-Selling Books Week Ended March 9
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Fewer People Seek Asylum in Europe
summary: Mediterranean crossings have fallen sharply as EU authorities and national governments have clamped down on migration routes. ROME-Asylum applications in European Union countries have dropped to levels seen before the migration crisis erupted in 2015, showing the effects of European governments' efforts to slow the inflow of refugees and other migrants that has caused political friction across the continent.

title: November Trial Date Set for Roger Stone
summary: Confidant of President Trump faces obstruction-of-justice and perjury charges. WASHINGTON-Roger Stone, a longtime Republican political consultant and confidant of President Trump, will go on trial in the fall on charges that he lied under oath and tried to obstruct a congressional investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

title: 2020 Porsche 911: One Last Hurrah Before Going Electric
summary: By 2025 half of Porsche's product line will be hybridized or fully electric, according to the brand. In the meantime, Dan Neil tests the handsomely redesigned 911 and ponders its place in Porsche's future. THE HOTEL ELEVATOR opened on the garage level but the motion-sensor-activated lighting stayed asleep. It was 3:30 a.m. and I was pulling out of Stuttgart in the midst of a winter storm, on my way to the Geneva auto show 300 miles away. Somewhere in the dark waited a 2020 Porsche 911 Carrera S, in Guard Red, the eighth generation of the company's humpbacked, ass-engined masterpiece. Notice I didn't call it icon.

title: Astronaut Buzz Aldrin, Children Drop Guardianship Fight
summary: The Aldrin family truce announcement came a few months before the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 mission this July. Buzz Aldrin, the Apollo 11 astronaut and moon walker, said he and his two children had resolved their legal battles over guardianship of his legacy and money.

title: Amtrak Struggles to Screen Workers for Drug, Alcohol Abuse, Report Finds
summary: Inspector General's report finds major flaws in substance-abuse testing system. WASHINGTON-Hundreds of Amtrak employees have slipped past the railroad's drug and alcohol testing regime in recent years, a new report says, even as the railroad's management has pledged to tighten screening in the wake of a fatal 2016 crash.

title: WPP Will Pay Sorrell More Than $2 Million in Shares as Part of Long-Term Bonus
summary: It is an about-face for WPP, which has frequently sparred with Mr. Sorrell since he left the firm last year. WPP PLC said it would pay its former Chief Executive Martin Sorrell shares worth more than 2 million pounds, or $2.65 million, as part of his long-term bonus, despite having threatened to withhold the payment following his departure from the firm.

title: Feds Search for Weapons Stolen From ATF Facility
summary: A contractor has been accused of stealing gun parts and firearms, some of them still missing. Federal agents around the country are scrambling to recover gun parts, ammunition and firearms that were stolen from a government disposal site, officials said.

title: Trump's Pick for World Bank Presidency Faces Clear Path
summary: David Malpass is set to assume leadership this year after deadline for other candidates passes. President Trump's pick to lead the World Bank, Treasury official David Malpass, will almost certainly assume the bank's presidency this year, after the deadline for countries to nominate candidates passed with no other challengers.

title: Toyota to Boost U.S. Investment to Nearly $13 Billion by 2021
summary: Japanese auto maker says it will create 600 new U.S. jobs, increase engine production at Alabama plant. Toyota Motor Corp. on Thursday raised its planned investment in its U.S. operations through 2021 by about a third to nearly $13 billion to build more models and parts in the country, a move that comes as the Trump administration considers imposing tariffs of up to 25% on auto imports.

title: NATO Members Lift Military Spending, but Remain Below Goals
summary: Alliance's report documents increases fueled by Russian aggression and berating by President Trump; Stoltenberg urges Germany to do more. BRUSSELS-NATO members are nudging up military spending in response to Russian aggression and hectoring from President Trump, but remain far from their spending goals, according to an alliance report.

title: Commerce Secretary Ross Denies 'Nefarious Purpose' in Crafting 2020 Census
summary: Ross says citizenship question is needed to get voting-rights data; Democrats say it will inhibit minorities from participating. WASHINGTON-Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross on Thursday said he had no "nefarious purpose" in crafting the 2020 census as lawmakers pressed him on why he added a citizenship question to the decennial count.

title: These 5 New Ships Are Redefining the 'Cruise'
summary: For more adventurous, less snoozy sea and river voyages-sailing in the Galápagos, Iceland, even Zanzibar-check out these new and soon-to-launch cruise ships. THE SHIP: Billing itself as the first hybrid cruise ship and launching this summer, the 265-cabin MS Roald Amundsen from 126-year-old Norwegian line Hurtigruten will be partly fueled by liquefied biogas-a renewable gas made from organic waste. You'd never know the ship is so granola: Designed by Rolls-Royce, it's kitted out with flourishes like an infinity pool on deck 10, stylish Scandinavian furnishings and outdoor hot tubs for the aft suites. Shore excursions tend to be sporty, like a guided hike in Antarctica or a snowmobile safari in Norway.

title: The Dreamy '60s Santa Monica Home of a Hollywood Super-Manager
summary: Inspired by touring a Le Corbusier home in Paris with her client Julianne Moore, Hollywood producer Evelyn O'Neill recreated the villa's exact paint pigments for her 1960s beach home-complete with ocean views that stretch all the way to Malibu. For Julianne Moore and Evelyn O'Neill, summer 2015 was the season of Le Corbusier. On a trip to Paris, the actress and her manager first visited the Centre Pompidou for a retrospective of the pioneering modern architect's work. But it was a tour of Maison La Roche, the airy, light-filled home Le Corbusier and his cousin Pierre Jeanneret designed for Swiss banker Raoul La Roche (now a UNESCO World Heritage site) that was the most transformative. Moore had been trying to convince O'Neill to redo her Santa Monica home for some time. "The thing about Maison La Roche is it looks like California," says Moore, "and the thing about Evelyn's apartment-the light in there is spectacular, and the way the space is organized-is it's reminiscent of Le Corbusier."

title: Talk to Trump, Skip the Diplomats: World Leaders' New U.S. Tactic
summary: Heads of state are bypassing standard government processes and going to the president himself to discuss policy. WASHINGTON-World leaders have found a new route to get a read on official U.S. thinking: straight to the top.

title: Facebook Goes a-Courtin'
summary: Facebook faces more court time as federal prosecutors probe into its data deals. Facebook got an early anniversary gift this morning. Unfortunately, it is a date with New York City courts.

title: Photos: A Top Hollywood Manager's Colorful 1960s Home in L.A.
summary: Touring Evelyn O'Neill's Santa Monica dream condo. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Bronx Program Teaches 10-Year-Olds Age-Appropriate Sex Ed
summary: After-school sessions build on New York City's efforts to expand health-education instruction. During the day, fifth-graders at P.S. 218 in the Bronx learn geography, fractions and life sciences. After school, they learn all about puberty-from menstruation to erections.

title: He Makes Suits for Sports Stars. He Is Also a Fugitive.
summary: Resume Subscription. Last year, 30 NFL players attended the "Pro Athlete Business Combine," an event for players to learn financial know-how from speakers including the Miami Dolphins owner and LeBron James's business manager.

title: GE's Glass-Half-Full Outlook
summary: A sobering outlook from GE on Thursday sent the shares higher as investors spotted a path to recovery for the troubled conglomerate.. Do you want the bad news or the good news first?

title: Smollett Pleads Not Guilty to Lying to Police Over Alleged Attack
summary: 'Empire' actor accused of paying brothers to participate in staged racist and antigay assault in Chicago. Actor Jussie Smollett pleaded not guilty in a Chicago court Thursday to multiple counts of lying to police when he reported being the victim of a racist and anti-gay attack in late January, his lawyer said.

title: Treasury to Sell $98 Billion in Debt
summary: U.S. Treasury Department plans to auction next week 13- and 26-week bills and 10-year TIPS. The U.S. Treasury Department will auction $98 billion in securities next week, comprising $39 billion in new debt and $59 billion in previously sold debt. summary: Ethiopian Airlines investigation, now crucial in the aircraft's grounding, moves to France. The black boxes from Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302 arrived in France early Thursday for analysis, a key step in a probe that could help determine how long Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX jetliner remains grounded around the world.

title: Amazon Cloud Doesn't Darken MongoDB Outlook
summary: Revenue has more than doubled in past two years at small seller of open-source database service. The problem with being a small cloud software company these days is that your fate seems highly dependent on the whims of Amazon , the biggest player in cloud computing.

title: The Quantum Computers in Our Future
summary: New systems using 'qubits' instead of classical bits will be vastly more powerful-but they still face important obstacles. In recent years there has been a lot of progress in the field of quantum computers. IBM, Google and Microsoft are big players, as are several university-based research groups and national laboratories around the world. There is a widespread sense that the technology has great promise, but the exact nature and scope of that promise has been only vaguely defined. Indeed, it's becoming clear that quantum computers will come in a variety of different sizes and shapes, suited for different purposes.

title: White House to Consider Expanding Penalty Reprieve to Taxpayers Adjusting to New Law
summary: Individuals' refunds are varying more than usual, with some workers who got their tax cuts throughout the year now expected to owe. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration will consider expanding penalty relief for taxpayers who had too little income taxes withheld from their paychecks and will aim to make a decision within a week, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said Thursday.

title: We Were Promised Space Colonies. What Went Wrong?
summary: Resume Subscription. I was an 11-year-old at Space Camp when I realized I was never going to space. This was July 1986, just six months after the space shuttle Challenger exploded on live TV, taking the lives of seven astronauts. The mood at the U.S. Space & Rocket Center in Huntsville, Ala., was understandably somber. NASA, still investigating the O-ring failure that caused the tragedy, hadn't slated any new missions. We were astronauts-to-be with no plans for liftoff. We ate freeze-dried Neapolitan ice cream, posed for pictures next to massive rockets, rode in a giant centrifuge and went home.

title: Preserving an Ancient Holiday of Light and Life
summary: The 60,000-strong Parsi community of India is bringing the celebration of the Zoroastrian new year into the 21st century. Every year in the third week of March, Manijeh Irani, 64, makes a tour of the markets of her adopted city, Mumbai-grocery stores, stalls of fresh and dried fruit, sweet shops, even an aquarium-for goods to adorn her festive table for Nowruz, the Persian New Year.

title: For These Homeowners, More Is More
summary: Some investors are buying multiple properties in the same development. Financial planners generally hate the idea, but these owners wouldn't do it any other way.. Bob Sage has a dream-and a strategy for achieving it. He wants a $7 million to $10 million condo with unobstructed ocean views in Ward Village, a multiuse development under construction in Honolulu, Hawaii. To get there, he's buying five units from the project's developer.

title: Job Slowdown Isn't Imaginary
summary: Rising unemployment insurance claims add to evidence that the U.S. job market has softened. The job market really is slowing.

title: Steve Wynn Met With Treasury Officials About Opportunity Zones After Stock Sale
summary: The meeting occurred after the casino magnate resigned from his company and from the Republican National Committee in the wake of sexual-misconduct allegations. Former casino executive Steve Wynn generated $2.1 billion and a big potential tax bill last March when he was forced to sell his stake in Wynn Resorts Ltd. after sexual-misconduct allegations. Less than three months later, he held a meeting with Treasury Department officials as they were writing regulations for a new tax incentive that had the potential to help him defer and reduce those taxes.

title: Winnetka Is An Expensive Slice of Americana
summary: Near Chicago, this town has small town feel on a big, waterfront-view budget.. Only 17 miles north of the 2.7-million-person city of Chicago, the 3.81-square-mile village of Winnetka feels outside of time: Family-owned businesses last for generations, residents are welcomed by name at the local pharmacy and neighborhood grocery stores offer house accounts. Winnetka-with about 12,200 residents and a median household income of $216,875, according to census data-is bordered by Lake Michigan to the east and the 894-acre Skokie Lagoons nature preserve to the west. The walkable community has three downtown districts, each with a train station for commuter rail service to Chicago, home to the headquarters of 27 Fortune 500 companies.

title: Former Sony Chief Howard Stringer Lists Fifth Avenue Home for $21 Million
summary: The retired executive and his wife are moving back to England after over five decades in the U.S.. Howard Stringer, former chief executive of Sony , is selling his longtime apartment on New York's Fifth Avenue for $21 million.

title: Labor Lawyer Takes On Mexico's Exporters, Wins Higher Wages
summary: Susana Prieto builds a following among employees seeking to reorganize, in biggest strike movement in 30 years. MATAMOROS, Mexico-The heads of a Coca-Cola bottler in this border city arrived at their closed plant this month armed with a court order that declared a strike by the company's workers illegal. Standing in their way was Susana Prieto.

title: Robots Will End Up Goofing Off Like the Rest of Us
summary: Sure, they're coming for our jobs. But won't they get bored?. Americans justifiably fear that robots are going to take our jobs. Tireless, immune to disease, not given to heavy partying, robots can build cars, brew venti lattes and even write short, humorous newspaper columns faster and more efficiently than humans. Way more efficiently.

title: Whitaker Didn't Deny Discussing Cohen Probe With Trump, Nadler Says
summary: House judiciary panel chief says ex-attorney general also was involved in talks over firing U.S. attorneys. WASHINGTON-Former acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker was involved in conversations about the scope of New York federal prosecutors' investigation into Michael Cohen, President Trump's former lawyer, and about whether to fire one or more U.S. attorneys, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee said Wednesday.

title: JPMorgan Trading Desk Lends Ukraine $350 Million
summary: Unusual private-bond placement could deliver $6 million trading profit. JPMorgan Chase & Co. lent about $350 million to Ukraine's government Tuesday, two weeks before a presidential election in the cash-strapped Eastern European country.

title: What Women Artists Knew About Work
summary: The lives of figures like Harriet Beecher Stowe and Helen Frankenthaler hold lessons for everyone about focus and perseverance. In December 1850, Harriet Beecher Stowe wrote to her sister-in-law with a complaint that will sound familiar to anyone who has struggled to carve out time for a creative project. "Since I began this note," Stowe wrote, "I have been called off at least a dozen times-once for the fish-man, to buy a codfish-once to see a man who had brought me some baskets of apples-once to see a book man...then to nurse the baby-then into the kitchen to make a chowder for dinner and now I am at it again, for nothing but deadly determination enables me to ever write-it is rowing against wind and tide."

title: How Do Sommeliers Do It? The Tricks to a Polished Pour
summary: Our wine columnist tapped three top sommeliers to school her in the art of serving wine with finesse. EVERY ACCOMPLISHED athlete has a coach. The same can be true of wine drinkers-and wine columnists, too. Even the most seasoned oenophile can use a refresher on the basics.
